content.description: A jug start leads to some crimpy holds and sharp rock over the bulge.
content.protection: Sling the large block on top
content.location: Just around the right of Traffic Jam

climbs.name: Unleadened
climbs.fa: J Herring and H D Johnson

content.description: The direct line a few feet L of Low Octane. I don't know if you can TR this or not, but MP requirements dictate that if you select "other" you also have to select TR. Lame, but WTFCIS...
content.location: L of Low Octane about 2 or 3 feet. Refer to the photo on the Low Octane page. It is the straight, red, dashed line L of LO.

content.description: This route follows the obvious crack on the right side of the wall.  A bouldery start leads to the crack and some combination of hand jams, layback, stems, pockets and crimps.  It eases off a bit as it goes up but it's sustained enough to maintain interest. It takes gear well and has good stances once you climb past the start.  Two anchor bolts on top. Walk off
content.protection: Medium cams and stoppers.  Two top anchor bolts
content.location: Rightmost end of the south face directly below the huge boulder on top

content.description: A somewhat contrived route on the left side of the wall.  Move right immediately off the ground to avoid easier ground and to gain a highly featured bulge.  Pull over the bulge on large jugs and stay right to the top.
content.protection: Sling the large block on top or gear redirect of 'High Octane' anchor
content.location: Left end of the south face where the landing begins to slope up the hill

content.description: A steep bouldery face/seam just left of center is protected by two bolts on top.  I haven't topped this one...for I am weak...so my assigned rating is a guess.  I suspect this is a Bob Murray high-ball boulder problem.
content.location: Center of the face below the diagonal trending seam

content.description: Climb up the south face between the hollow flakes on the left and right to join the crack near the top.  Watch out for loose rock
content.protection: Sling a large chockstone behind the top for an anchor
content.location: This route is in the center of a separate outcropping 20 yards to the left and a little uphill of the main crag.

content.description:
An outcropping with a large boulder on top sits just right and uphill of the cluster of power poles on the north side of the road. This outcropping has short routes on its south side. Each route is just under 35 ft high.

 I don't know who originally put up the routes with fixed anchors.  Names and FA info all subject to change
